title: Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Factor’s road bikes compared
content:
Cyclist
Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Factor’s road bikes compared

Factor’s road bike range has for a while consisted only of the pro-level Ostro VAM lightweight/aero all-rounder race bike and O2 VAM lightweight climber’s bike. But these bikes were joined in April 2025 by the Monza, a bike that looks to simplify the design of the Ostro VAM to lower fabrication costs, while still retaining its aero features. That lowers the Monza’s price, while Factor’s changes are also aimed at making the Monza easier to live with.

The VAM in the names of Factor’s pro-level bikes denotes velocità ascensionale media (average ascent velocity) – a nod to the bikes’ low weight. We’re yet to review the Monza, but have been impressed by both the Ostro VAM and the O2 VAM in our reviews. 

That’s not all from Factor, because it also sells the (non-VAM) O2 road bike and the Ostro Gravel and LS gravel bikes, as well as a host of time trial and track bikes and even a hardtail and a full-sus MTB.

But which Factor road bike is right for you? Read on for our in-depth comparison.

Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Key features at a glance

Factor Ostro VAM

  • Aero road bike with low weight
  • Slender frontal profile to reduce drag
  • 32mm tyre clearance
  • CeramicSpeed bearings throughout
  • Top spec groupset choices
  • Black Inc 48|58 wheelset as standard

Factor Monza

  • Less aggressive stack and reach than Ostro VAM
  • Similar frame geometry to Ostro VAM
  • Includes internal storage 
  • 34mm tyre clearance
  • Steel bearings and standard round head tube
  • SRAM Force AXS or Ultegra builds and frameset-only
  • Black Inc 45 wheelset as standard

Factor O2 VAM

  • Lightweight with aero leanings
  • Same stack and reach as the Monza
  • Integrated seatmast
  • 32mm tyre clearance
  • CeramicSpeed bearings
  • Top spec electronic groupset options
  • Equipped with 1,198g Black Inc 28|33 climbing wheels

Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Intent 

Factor’s road bikes have always been targeted at the premium end of the market. It’s had a sponsored pro team since 2016, when its bikes were ridden by One Pro Cycling and it debuted in the WorldTour with AG2R La Mondiale team in 2017.

Since 2020, it’s sponsored the Israel-Premier Tech men’s team, to which it added the Human Powered Health women’s WorldTour team in 2025. Despite Israel-Premier Tech currently sitting in the second tier of pro teams, it garners invitations to most major races, including all three grand tours in 2025. As a member of the Women’s WorldTour, Human Powered Health has automatic entry to all the top races.

The Ostro VAM and O2 VAM are targeted principally at the top end of racing, with both ridden by Factor’s sponsored pros. Factor sharpened up the O2 VAM in 2023, aiming to provide a better platform for pro-level climbers. With a 730g claimed frame weight, we weighed our review bike in size 56 at 6.5kg, so a complete ready-to-race bike will sit almost exactly on the 6.8kg limit. 

The second generation Ostro VAM shed around 270g in weight from its predecessor when it was launched in early 2024. That though was principally from the new 1,290g claimed weight Black Inc 48|58 wheelset, rather than a significant reduction in frame weight, which is quoted at 820g. Factor says that’s about as light as it can get without sacrificing stiffness and ride feel. Our test bike in size 54 came up at 7.1kg. It’s more aero than the previous model, making it a top level aero/lightweight bike contender.

In contrast, the Monza is a bike designed more around the needs of the amateur rider, who may have to race and train on the same bike and won’t be riding the smooth, newly laid tarmac often rolled out for the pros. Factor claims an 1,100g frame weight.

Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Design, carbon fibre and fabrication 

Factor uses a mix of premium grade carbon fibre in both the Ostro VAM and the O2 VAM. This includes Nippon Graphite pitch-based fibre and Toray fibre alongside TeXtreme spread tow fibre, which increases the carbon-to-resin ratio, reducing weight.

Factor says that the Monza’s carbon layup has been selected to reduce the cost of materials. It omits the TeXtreme carbon fibre, but still uses the same grades of Toray and Nippon Graphite carbon. The Monza is claimed by Factor to offer the same frame stiffness and ride feel as the Ostro VAM though.

Factor has also made some changes in the design, to make the Monza easier to build. These include a wider radius of curvature to the seatstays and a less elaborate interface between the fork crown and the head tube.

The O2 VAM’s ultra-light design didn’t allow Factor to use a conventional seatpost, hence the seatmast and topper, which it says also allowed it to build in improved compliance at the saddle.

Factor is an unusually integrated bike company, with design, testing, fabrication, finishing and assembly all done in-house in its factories in Taiwan, rather than framebuilding being outsourced to a third party, which it says allows it to maintain better control over the whole process. It’s also able to prototype new designs much faster than its peers, it says.

Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Aerodynamics

The current, second generation Ostro VAM has been designed for optimum aero performance. This comes principally from a thin frontal profile, to reduce the surface aero presented to the wind. 

The head tube is also longer than that of its predecessor, taking advantage of changes in the UCI’s tube profile regulations. 

The Monza copies many of the Ostro VAM’s tube profiles, but it’s less slimmed down and so presents a slightly larger surface area to the wind. The head tube is wider and accommodates a standard round steerer in place of the Ostro VAM’s thinner design and D-shaped steerer.

At the rear, although still aero the Monza’s seatpost is less skinny than the Ostro VAM’s and the same as used in the first generation Ostro VAM. This allows the in-frame battery on Shimano-equipped bikes to be housed in the seatpost, rather than needing to be inserted into the seat tube via the bottom bracket, as on the Ostro VAM.

Although the frame itself is less out-and-out aero than the Ostro VAM, Factor says that its wind tunnel testing results are similar. It says its testing also found that the inclusion of in-frame storage in the Monza, allowing spares to be stashed away, saves 6 watts versus using a saddle pack.

While the Ostro VAM exploits the UCI’s latest rule changes to make tube shapes longer, the O2 VAM does the opposite, making the top tube thinner relative to its breadth, particularly at its rear.

The airfoil shapes in the O2 VAM are more truncated than those on the Ostro VAM, as deeper shapes equal more material and hence more weight.  

Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Geometry

Factor’s geometry figures are very similar between the three bikes, as shown below for a size 56 frame for each.

Seat tube length524680*519
Seat tube angle73.5°73.5°73.5°
Head tube angle73.3°73.3°73.3°
Bottom bracket drop707070
Chainstay length405405405
Frame reach392389389
Frame stack565574574
Wheelbase987987987

* Includes seatmast

The main difference is a longer reach and lower stack for the Ostro VAM than for the other two bikes, which share the same reach and stack figures. That reflects the Ostro VAM’s aero performance objectives – pros want to get long and low on their bikes to lower their frontal profile and will have trained for this position.

As a climbing bike, the O2 VAM’s ride position is more upright, as climbers in general prefer a less stretched out position, as they want to maximise their oxygen intake and be able to stand and sit more easily, Factor says.

The Monza duplicates the O2 VAM’s reach and stack, which Factor says is ‘more democratic’ than the Ostro VAM’s and likely to be more comfortable for more riders, without needing to resort to a chunky stack of spacers.

Available sizes for all three bikes are 45, 49, 52, 54, 56, 59 and 61cm.

Toe overlap can be an issue with smaller frame sizes, but for the O2 VAM, for example, Factor has four different forks with different offsets, so that its trail is the same across frame sizes, without having to slacken the head tube angle on smaller bikes.

Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Wheelsets

Factor fits wheels from its Black Inc component brand, which achieve low weight and, Factor claims, aero efficiency. It co-develops wheelsets alongside its bikes.

On the Ostro VAM, the standard wheelset is the 1,290g Black Inc 48|58, which incorporates aero carbon spokes and CeramicSpeed bearings. It’s made of a mix of T-700, T-800 and T-1100 carbon fibre.

With its focus on low weight, the O2 VAM has the lower profile Black Inc 28|33 wheelset fitted. The rim is a mix of T-700 and T-800 carbon fibre and here too there are CeramicSpeed bearings. The claimed weight drops to 1,198g.

The Monza’s Black Inc 45 wheelset focuses on serviceability, with steel spokes and steel bearings. Factor hasn’t provided a figure for the wheelset’s weight. 

Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Handlebars and seatpost

Factor relies on Black Inc for its handlebars too. All three bikes are supplied with a one piece bar/stem with internal cable routing.

The Ostro VAM comes with the AB02 model. It has a 398g claimed weight for a 420mm x 110mm bar/stem and is available with 360mm to 420mm widths and 80mm to 140mm effective stem length. There’s a classic wide-but-thin aero profile to the tops and a 120mm drop with a 7 degree flare to the drops.

On the O2 VAM, the fitted bar/stem is the Black Inc HB01 with a 320g claimed weight. It’s available in widths from 380mm to 440mm and with stem lengths from 90mm to 130mm. The drop is 120mm and the flare to the drops is 3 degrees.

The Monza is fitted with the Black Inc HB04. Its effective reach and drop numbers are smaller than the bar/stems fitted to the other two bikes and its profile less thin and sharp-edged, which Factor says makes it easier to grasp for a range of hand sizes. 

Factor claims a 440g weight for a 400x110mm bar/stem. It’s available in 360mm, 380mm and 400mm widths and with six stem lengths from 80mm to 130mm. The drop is 116mm and the flare to the drops is 7 degrees.

Black Inc also supplies the seatpost, with 0mm and 25mm setback options for the Monza, 0mm or 20mm setback for the Ostro VAM. The O2 VAM’s seatmast topper is available in 0mm or 25mm setback and three lengths, standard, short or long to provide different levels of adjustability.

Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Groupsets

Factor’s bikes are compatible with electronic groupsets only and it offers a range of premium options from SRAM and Shimano. You can choose SRAM Red AXS or Force AXS for the Ostro VAM and the O2 VAM, both with a 48/35t power meter crankset and 10-33t cassette.

Shimano builds feature either Dura-Ace or Ultegra, with a 52/36t crankset without a power meter and an 11-30t cassette. 

The Factor Monza is offered with either SRAM Force AXS with a power meter or Ultegra without a power meter, with the same available ratios.

While many brands spec 172.5mm crank length on all but their smallest bikes, the Monza is fitted with 165mm cranks on the size 45 and 48 frames and 170mm cranks from size 52 up to size 56, while the 58 is the smallest bike to step up to 172.5mm cranks.

Buyers of both the Ostro VAM and O2 VAM can choose cranks from 165mm to 175mm for Shimano builds or 165mm to 172.5mm for SRAM builds, regardless of their selected frame size.

Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Available builds compared

You can buy all three of Factor’s bikes frameset-only or as a frameset with wheels in the case of the Ostro VAM and O2 VAM, if you want to choose your own build. Otherwise there are standard builds which feature high quality groupset and wheelset choices.

Factor Ostro VAM vs Monza vs O2 VAM: Which should you choose?

If you’re looking for a premium road bike, the choice between the Ostro VAM and the O2 VAM is finely balanced, as they’re pretty close in purpose and in price and spec levels.

At 6.5kg, the O2 VAM is impressively lightweight and one of the best lightweight road bikes. You’re not likely to be held back on the climbs by the 7.1kg Ostro VAM either, which makes a good case for being one of the best all-round road race bikes available. 

The use of a seatmast rather than a separate seatpost can be a negative for some potential buyers, but the O2 VAM’s multiple length and setback toppers provide options to accommodate different fit requirements.

We’ve not got a weight available for the Monza and have yet to review it, but with less premium carbon fibre, second tier groupsets and the Black Inc 45 wheels, the weight will be higher. Probably not bad, but not pro-level.

On the other hand, for most riders the Monza is likely to be a more accommodating bike. It’s slightly more relaxed, allows you to fit wider tyres and has the space to stash your ride essentials out of the wind – a handy feature for riders without a team car to sort out mechanicals or give them a spare bike.

The Monza isn’t just more affordable to purchase, its more standard specs and lower priced components will be cheaper to maintain too.

If you’ve set your heart on a premium race bike, both the Ostro VAM and O2 VAM are compelling alternatives to the Pinarello Dogma, Trek Madone and S-Works Tarmac though. The choice between them probably comes down to whether you ride more in the hills and see yourself as a climber or on the flat, seeing yourself as more of an all-round racer.
